results.title: Interview with Giovanni Sgro - President FILEF Australia
results.brief_description: This 30 minute interview with the president of FILEF Australia, Giovanni Sgro, was produced in ACMI’s screen pit in December of 2003. Roberta Ciabarra conducts a delightful interview with Giovanni, in which he recalls his own experience of migration and starting a new life in this country. He also provides valuable insights into the history of migrant workers and their impact on the politics and development of Australia. Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).

results.title: Racconti: La Voce del popolo = The Voice of the people
results.brief_description:
Racconti: La Voce Del Popolo (The Voice of the People) is a powerful living memory and dedication to the lives of hard working Australian/Italians and celebrates the enormous contribution they have made to this country.
Through the Digital storytelling program at the Australian Centre for Moving Image (ACMI) the 10 storytellers were guided through the telling of a personal story using multimedia tools. The participants used their voice as narrative and combined the audio-visual resources of their personal archives (photographs, video footage, text, music and sound) and each storyteller has produced a 3 - 5 minute digital story that explores their experiences of migration and settlement.
Racconti: La Voce Del Popolo (the Voice of the People) was made possible through the partnership of the Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF) and the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) with the support of the Victorian Multicultural Commission.

results.title: Maniac de Luxe
results.material_description: two-channel video, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description: A dual screen video installation with thematic furnishing elements including low light household lamps, Maniac de Luxe interrogates the implications of private activities relocated into public space. Through a conceptual focus in the screen images on the interiors of large designer furnishing outlets and the cross cutting of footage on one screen between these public interiors and private dwellings which feature similar furnishings, the realm of private and public is increasing blurred and their boundaries rendered increasingly ambiguous. On a large rear projection screen, a group of characters sit and discuss private thoughts and issues in a designer furniture showroom, a further problematic to the division between private and public space. An ambient soundtrack along with two discrete soundscapes including dialogue from a group of characters and original music, will also inform the atmosphere of the installation, itself furnished as a room in a generic designer home.

results.title: Stuck on a hot roof
results.creator_credit: Tay Li Nar and School of Creative Media RMIT
results.brief_description: CD-ROM completed as part of Major Project in second year of RMIT Bachelor of Arts in Multimedia. Inspired by the conventional comic strip’s linear format the work attempts to both work within and reinforce the conventions of a left to right frame sequenvce as well as explore the possibilities of breaking these parameters. This prototype interactive comic strip allows for multiple narratives and breaks the sequence to create variable storylines. Suitable for most age groups; contains low level offensive language.
